<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 551, 89]]<|/det|>
A student determines the density of a block of wood.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 707, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows one face of the block of wood that the student uses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 128, 645, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 335, 532, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 181, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 885, 384]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(l\) and width \(w\) of the block of wood. Fig. 1.1 is drawn actual size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[584, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>l = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 443, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<form>w = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 490, 181, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 489, 660, 509]]<|/det|>
The student measures the height \(h\) of the block of wood.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 521, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<form>h = .................................................... $4.0$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 555, 828, 575]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the block of wood using the equation \(V = l \times w \times h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 587, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<form>V = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 619, 180, 638]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 619, 769, 638]]<|/det|>
The student measures the mass \(m\) of the block of wood on a balance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 645, 594, 720]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 736, 534, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 766, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
Write down the mass \(m\) of the block as shown in Fig. 1.2. Give your answer to the nearest gram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[573, 813, 920, 832]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 813, 920, 832]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 83, 180, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 79, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the wood using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment and include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[578, 170, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
<form>ρ = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 202, 146, 221]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 201, 920, 237]]<|/det|>
The student places the block of wood carefully in water in a glass dish. The wood floats as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 242, 814, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 401, 534, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 433, 181, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
Using Fig. 1.3, estimate, without taking a measurement, the volume \(V_{1}\) of wood that is below the water surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 492, 920, 514]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = ................................................. cm^{3} [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 526, 181, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 526, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(m_{W}\), the mass of water with volume \(V_{1}\), using the equation \(m_{W} = \rho_{W} \times V_{1}\), where \(\rho_{W} = 1.00\) in the same units as \(\rho\) in part (a)(iv).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 618, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
<form>m_W = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 144, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that the mass \(m\) of the block of wood should be equal to the mass \(m_{W}\) of the water with volume \(V_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 183, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 695, 698, 714]]<|/det|>
Calculate the difference \(d\) between your values of \(m\) and \(m_{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 740, 920, 760]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 774, 181, 792]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 772, 811, 792]]<|/det|>
Discuss whether the difference \(d\) is small enough to conclude that \(m = m_{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 804, 920, 823]]<|/det|>
<form>...............................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 835, 920, 853]]<|/det|>
<form>...............................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 865, 920, 883]]<|/det|>
<form>...............................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 866, 920, 885]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Another student wants to obtain a more accurate value for \(V_{1}\). He uses the method of floating the block of wood in water as described in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 875, 135]]<|/det|>
Suggest how the student could obtain a more accurate value by taking a measurement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 240, 920, 257]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 636, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistances of a resistor and a lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 475, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the first circuit arrangement.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 129, 727, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 370, 532, 389]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 146, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 402, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
She records \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\), the potential difference (p.d.) across the resistor R, and the current \(I_{\mathrm{S}}\) in the circuit. The meters are shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 181, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 450, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
Write down the readings. Include the units for potential difference, current or resistance where appropriate in all parts of the question.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 491, 465, 660]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 492, 878, 660]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 675, 326, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[670, 675, 742, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 720, 917, 740]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{\mathrm{S}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 752, 917, 771]]<|/det|>
<form>I_{\mathrm{S}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 769, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 816, 180, 834]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 808, 779, 839]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\), the resistance of resistor R, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{S}}}{I_{\mathrm{S}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 876, 920, 896]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{\mathrm{S}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 878, 920, 896]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The student replaces the resistor with the lamp. She records \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) the potential difference across the lamp and the current \(I_{\mathrm{L}}\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 116, 917, 141]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>L</sub> = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[574, 152, 920, 176]]<|/det|>
<form>I<sub>L</sub> = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 728, 228]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{L}}\), the resistance of the lamp, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{L}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{L}}}{I_{\mathrm{L}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 276, 920, 297]]<|/det|>
<form>R<sub>L</sub> = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[868, 277, 920, 297]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 144, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
The student connects the resistor R in series with the lamp. She connects the voltmeter to record \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\), the potential difference across the series combination of the resistor and the lamp. Draw the circuit diagram for this arrangement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 712, 146, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 711, 920, 746]]<|/det|>
The student records \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\) the potential difference across the resistor and the lamp in series and the current \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 755, 918, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>C</sub> = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[574, 794, 918, 816]]<|/det|>
<form>I<sub>C</sub> = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 829, 920, 887]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{C}}\), the combined resistance of the resistor and the lamp connected in series, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{C}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{C}}}{I_{\mathrm{C}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 924, 920, 944]]<|/det|>
<form>R<sub>C</sub> = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 925, 920, 944]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 554, 91]]<|/det|> A student investigates the image produced by a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 364, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 128, 866, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 289, 534, 308]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 146, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 320, 838, 339]]<|/det|> The student places the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 351, 166, 369]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 351, 814, 369]]<|/det|> He moves the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 382, 168, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 382, 814, 400]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 171, 431]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 412, 626, 433]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 3.1, \(\frac{u}{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 444, 171, 463]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 444, 920, 478]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure for \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(u = 40.0 \text{cm}\). The readings and results are shown in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 490, 541, 507]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 515, 663, 693]]<|/det|>
\(u/\text{cm}\)\(v/\text{cm}\)\(\frac {u}{v}\)
20.079.5
25.044.50.56
30.035.00.86
35.030.01.17
40.027.01.48
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the strengths of wires made from different metals by measuring the force required to break the wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 4.1. A wire is held by a clamp at one end and a load is suspended from the other end. The load is increased until the wire breaks. The student takes all the necessary safety precautions.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 176, 608, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 358, 532, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 389, 897, 407]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the force required to break wires made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 420, 438]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 314, 469]]<|/det|>
clamps and stands

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 524, 485]]<|/det|>
a selection of masses with a suitable hanger

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 243, 500]]<|/det|>
metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 546, 515]]<|/det|>
a selection of wires made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 529, 907, 547]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 324, 578]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 592, 138, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 680, 609]]<|/det|>
write a list of suitable metals for the wires you would investigate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 136, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 622, 566, 640]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 654, 138, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 654, 591, 672]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 138, 703]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 685, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 732, 136, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 732, 655, 749]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 576, 89]]<|/det|>
You may add to the diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 833, 120]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to write about the safety precautions that the student should take.
